Freud was deeply concerned about the issue of sexual boundaries in therapy, since many patients in psychoanalysis developed what he called transference; projecting desires or feelings onto the analyst.  He believed sexual involvement with patients would undermine therapy and considered it unethical (even by early 20th-century standards).  Historians agree that Freud did not engage sexually with his patients, though some of his followers (like Carl Jung) crossed those boundaries, which caused scandals at the time.   Freud did have close, sometimes emotionally charged relationships with some patients and colleagues, most famously with Sabina Spielrein. She was first Jungâ€™s patient, not Freudâ€™s

@hubermanlab, thank you for hosting Mr. Greene, and after a tbi in mma and a car accident last year, i've had a wonderful arduous journey exploring rewiring my brain with some nifty yale students and i feel that, in my study of social science and engineering, there are individuals such as myself that survive moreso through the mammalian brain and to be engaged in modern society at times, I know, is a very unique experience, understand that my space in time feels to me, to be that more of a shark in water, than an average person trying to just live his life.   skateboarding, mountain biking, poetry, painting, and various other nuanced practices, and i feel like a strange modern samurai, well, moreso a ronin, but i use the practice of "art" to get into the flow state, though i'm not the best at any of it, after multiple brain injuries, i myself, have gone through multiple changes, almost like puberty again, its weird.   i see student doctors from yale n stuff and i've always wanted to be one, like, i used to like sociology but the grander concept of Social Engineer is just a wild concept to me, so much so, i've dedicated almost a decade fighting the darkness of traumas and not becoming a statistic unless its for a positive reason, to figure out exactly what my purpose is and to fulfill it.   The way the two of you spoke of the expansion of our consciousness through that internal dialogue that can generate a flow state, its hard at times, but achieving it through a singular means, to me, was vary narrow minded, so i attempted multiples of activities simultaneously to activate the flow state to try and rewire the neurological damage that has occured in my brain.  That and mushrooms.   It has been working. I also try to teach people how to use their minds properly and it gets me in trouble sometimes.   Time is a lie and i think those who think not of it are the ones that live forever.   Where did time come from? the compass, not the sun dial, though we knew the sun and weather changed yet we did not yet know of "time." The compass was used in conjuction with the sun to follow declination toward or away from the sun at sea, in what was called, minutes and hours, and using that knowledge progressed human consciouness to derived and even more precise device that can predict the suns appearance and disappearance, the clock. minutes and hours left the compass and became the clocks named handles.   To percieve time is different than to exist in time.
Are you a believer by any chance?

Thank you for having @RobertGreeneOfficial on the podcast. I'm a UW Madison Alum & loved hearing of Robert Greene's insights. Dr. Huberman, your insights about your own purpose finding hit home for me. I was a kid who liked to turn over rocks in our back yard and look for all the little critters that would crawl away. Learning about biology became my passion from a young age. I also like learning new things and organizing that information.  I taught at the high school and middle school level for several years. Today, I work in the public health space. I'm a woman at age 50, who made certain choices to put career in the back seat while I raised children, who also have a passion for biology and science. All in all, it's been a good life so far. I thank you for bringing this great information to the forefront. I listen several times a week and learn something new that I can use in my personal life or teach in my classes in the community all the time. I have downloaded the book Mastery, to listen to soon. Again, many thanks for this interview and the many you put out into the world. It has helped me up my game in my personal life. The learning I do via Huberman Lab benefits my community in the classes I teach in Public Health. I know I'm passing along good information!!

Okay...Dolly Parton and her husbands long lasting love.  They blow away the idea that two very different music tastes are not compatible. Her husband loves punk. He didn't take an interest in country style but they chose to make it work. Relationships are so much effort and work. Love and interest won't make it work alone. Willingness to be there supportive of the other is what helps turbulent times.  Being bored by the person you are dating suggests an issue with the viewer, not the other person being boring. If I can't find anything new about someone it's because I am not paying attention.  Some people are water and oil. Some are water and roses. Some are water and flour. We are what we make of ourselves and others. We must take responsibility for our own feelings for a relationship to succeed and a human to grow. Always ask what am I not seeing to make someone more interesting.

My father left us and fractured my home when I was 8 or 9 years old. So, unfortunately for me, these early moments of inspiration, delight, and wonder in my childhood that may hint to the direction of my "unique seed" my "calling" is obfuscated by trauma, chaos, and pain. I can hardly remember those times; They're a vague shadow of a memory. At that time, my priorities shifted to survival and protection. I learned to shut off and ignore my emotions for the sake of providing emotional strength stability for my sister and my mother, who became a depressive wreck. Something that no little boy should have to do. I was emotionally numb and full of self-loathing all during my adolescence and into my early adulthood which caused me to miss out on so much. Meaningful friendships, dating, sex, and other social and developmental milestones.  I'm turning 37 this year and not only do I not have a past to look into for guidance, but I don't have an emotional compass to guide my present as I am still numb and emotionally stunted. I feel so incredibly lost and alone and without guidance and with no one to turn to for help. Well, at least not without paying for it, which I am too poor for such a luxury. Wild to think that emotional and mental health support is luxury in this country (US).

I really appreciate both of your insights, but the one thing that I've been thinking about is the lack of strong female role models for us to emulate (in comparison to men). Even the book Mastery had nearly all male role models. It's hard to be a career-oriented female, particularly in STEM, and not know who to look up to. Often our predecessors emulated the men out of necessity, so that's all we see as well and it seems like the only option. Same with all of the interesting podcasts like this being run by men and predominantly interviewing male experts. Not casting any blame, it is the way it is, but wondering if you have more examples you could bring on the show of femininity and strong career mastery.

I knew from childhood I wanted to be a dentist/orthodontist. I was obsessed with teeth and healthy smiles.  I did very well in school and grew up with teenage parents who were negligent.  I did well in school getting almost straight Aâ€™s until my junior year.  My parents never showed any interest in my future or my desire to go to college. One evening I interrupted my motherâ€™s chain smoking cosmopolitan reading evening and told her I wanted to go to college and I was in AP classes.  I was so exited. She looked at me with disgust! She said â€œcollege is for rich people, weâ€™re not rich and youâ€™re not going.  She was in her early 30â€™s when I was a teen and always resented me.  She didnâ€™t want me to achieve anything.  At that point I gave up on getting good grades and any chance for any scholarships was gone .  At the age of 17 my parents kicked me out because I was an hour late on a Saturday night. They were extremely strict finding myself being homeless at the age of 17. It took a job I could get and work as an office clerk for very little money. I did not have any drug or alcohol. I struggled to get up. The career path worked extremely hard and eventually went back to school when I was much older and got several college degrees as a single parent. but how do I know for sure that what I am experiencing is infact the actual true version of sublime? Is there even something like that or is it just supposed to be subjective? And I feel this for every emotion, sure, there are variants and levels. But if we look at it like there is no ultimate truth, just different versions of it for instance we all have come to a mutual understanding of this colour blue - to everyone it's called blue, but how do you know that the blue I'm seeing is the same as the blue you are seeing? And extending this theory to our feelings, like we experience something in the childhood this amazing butterfly tickle and the feeling of fulfillment , joy, everything yellow, of what we then think is love; only to realise later when we actually experience a feeling more divine within the same spectrum, that oh! that was nothing, this is it! only to maybe again, being defeated into feeling that way later in the future - which btw is something I adore ( to my optimum measure of adorability I have ever experienced till date ) . This metamorphosis of our feelings and us is amazing. But its somewhat complex when we try to look at the feeling of  " sublime " because that is so time bound, over a duration and not just that instantaneous feeling we somewhat somewhere at some moment had experienced. Because we can only achieve what we want to, and have to within the time we are alive. It's like a constant race. It's like maze runner with a ticking bomb on the shoulder. If you don't solve it BOOM. And all these complexities, this fight is just unidimensional right now in this very paragraph. Because this just talks about the evolution of "one feeling " towards that " one thing we think gives us that feeling " . If the later is also a variable, and not to mention its all thrown out and away off our individualistic selves, everything becomes so scattered. Like a freshly broken glass frozen in time, with all those small pieces dancing everywhere from everywhere. And with allllll of this going on, how does one infact find their purpose ? Or is it supposed to be like an illusion, a lie that we tell ourselves, a little trick, and ultimately wear it so many times, and master its drapery such that our mind speaks out for us and to us - here this is what you are here for, now go shooo. Is this entire process of hunting and gathering a mere story building we do for ourselves, without even noticing? I also often hear things like " you'll know when its time " but there have been times when i thought it was time only to have found that feeling swayed away by another wave of oh this time this is it for sure. It's by Dava Sobel, also has an edition with all sorts of historical illustration and a beautiful movie to go along with it. It really is commendable for everyone interested in cultural and scientific history - especially that of navigation and cartography - and that of one of the giants on whose shoulders we stand: John Harrison.  Tested by many trials and misfortunes he developed a chronometer that for the first time allowed the precise measurement of time at sea - and by that to determine the position of ships at sea. The chronometer earned its repuation on James Cooks second voyage... you see the waters of ingenuity and adventure this book takes you to.

I'm always wary of this idea that you can "read people like open books if you pay attention to their nonverbal communication." Although we can analyze external behaviors, much of the understanding we gain from them is rooted in interpretation, and we must always keep in mind that our interpretation may be wrong. Someone may give you a "fake smile" and you interpret it as them not really liking you, but you don't know that they just lost a family member and are upset about it, or someone looks like they're dying to walk away from you but you don't know they have a small child at home left unattended. I also noticed that most of the examples brought up around body language during the interview revolved around the idea "that this person is not really interested in you", which I think could very well be just a projection of how you perceive yourself more than how others perceive you. Anyway my main point is that none of us are omniscient, and we should always keep in mind that we can understand things completely wrong because we always look at the world through the distorted lens of subjectivity. Great podcast though, I enjoyed every minute of it.

At the end of your interview, you asked if there were any ideas about topics. I have one! I once watched an interview you did. Someone was interviewing you. You explained how you grew up in the skateboarding scene in Northern California. Over the last 20 years, i have watched and experienced not only my younger brother grew up in the Southern California skateboarding scene, but my son as well. In our small town we have brick roads or sidewalks so it is easy to get stopped by the police and get tickets. The city has since built a few skateparks in the area which takes the boarders  off the streets because it was very easy for a young skate boarder to be fully consumed by skateboarding one day then by hard drugs the next. Watching my brother (now 35) grow up in Redlands, California and his friends some escaped, and some just fall off the face 9f the Earth (i know not really). My brother has been consumed by drugs since prison/jail has become a reoccuring reality for him. Now, my son(27), also growing up in Redlands, California, has allowed himself the same realities. Years ago, there were skateshops that allowed kids to hang out all day and watch skateboarding videos. Where hard drugs were introduced, given and sold. This had a tremendous influence on the young men and then carried into adulthood.  Im not sure if this is so much the case now, but it makes for a great story or experiement. If effects me tremendously because my brother has to live with me, now recently released from prison.  My son prefers to live at the local park or under the freeway bridge. He comes home maybe once a week to shower and eat.  I heard your experiences with the skate parks and friends are a little similar. One good thing the city did was get the skaters off the streets. I just hope it was enough to give the younger a fighting chance at life.  Thank you. Rebecka

When I found out how our sub conscious really works, really felt like I had been cooking in this kitchen for years without using my sous chef. There was something I read that said how, when you find something randomly when you were not looking for it, its because its like you and your sub conscious are both trying to open the same file cabinet in your brain. I try to do things that expedite this process by just identifying what I want and then going back to what Im doing or flashing images in my head of where it could be. Its not perfect but sometimes its right on key.

if thereÂ´s one thing that triggers me, itÂ´s the theory of the "many intelligences" - Even Gardner, the inventor, was quick to admit, that he regretted that phrasing. He thought it sounded good, and it was a scheme to get the word "out there". He would have preferred to call it competences or "talents" instead. Why? because those are not determining factors. >Theyre nice to have, but you can do without. ergo - you can LEARN them. Intelligence however, is borderline impossible to train. Its inherent -  In that way Gardners theory actually limits the very people, he was trying to highlight as having "more".   the whole thing has been picked up by the universities, the humanistic faculties especially, and been regurgitated so many times, that we are now forced to listen to it. historyless and lackluster, indeed

This guy is full of shit. Says there is no formula, then goes on to be formulaic about how, when, as if his life is the same size, fit-all for everyone else.   People, even 50 year olds, don't listen to anyone. Inside all of us is happiness. Whether you think you found your "purpose" or not, it has no bearing on your innate ability to choose to be happy.   You can be happy and achieve absolutely nothing. You can wonder through life for 40 years full of regrets, and still decide to be happy.   Don't listen to men like this who pressure you into some sort of transactional recipe for happiness that is for some reason bound into finding a purpose, and the older you get without purpose the harder it becomes to be happy.  This is all lies. There is always hope, happiness is as easy as just letting go and allowing judgement, regret, expectations, failure to be what they are, simple thoughts.   You are NOT your thoughts. This man is obsessed with thinking your way into happiness. He calls it finding purpose, and is assuming that purpose fixes how you think and feel about yourself. That thought that he is trying to cultivate in you, it's just a thought.   Thinking can't truly make you happy. Letting go and allowing yourself to be happy is the way. Let life flow through you. Make peace and be happy.   Those who know donâ€™t talk. Those who talk donâ€™t know. Close your mouth, block off your senses, blunt your sharpness, untie your knots, soften your glare, settle your dust. This is the primal identity. Be like the Tao. It canâ€™t be approached or withdrawn from, benefited or harmed, honored or brought into disgrace. It gives itself up continually. That is why it endures.

We are not disembodied entities, to live as a human is to do, love and survive, ultimately transcend that, which is what heâ€™s talking about here. Can you let go of hunger or thirst? We still have to play by a set of rules in reality despite our best fantasies.

Finding Purpose, Childhood, Learning:  For me, my first thought was my fascination with colors, at 3 it was not just pink, it was magenta, I have always been someone fascinated by the details of not only what differentiates something, but why/how it is that way. How to make magenta pink? Even at 2, how to make my favorite animations? Let me try myself- Iâ€™ll draw Peterpan- has a breakdown over not being able to draw his neckâ€¦at 2. Why were letters the shapes they are? In kindergarten I went further in math because I didnâ€™t just want the answers, I wanted to know why it was the answer- even if that meant spending recess asking questions to the teacherâ€™s assistant of â€œwell what if I did x and x, would the answer still be x?â€ Same with grammar, â€œwhat if I put Because x, sentence, because x. 17:54 - is that ok? No? But the why is a clause sandwich â€œWhile x, sentence, because xâ€ ok?â€ Over time I guess I quickly learned no one has the time to explain to me why completely. So I stopped doing it as much. Up until freshman year of high school before I went into college level courses, I even understood my math courses to the extent I could make formulas to solve questions fasterâ€¦still went into engineering, but at that point- I was studying for answers not the whys. Why? (Lol) because at a certain level of academics they started teaching answers before the why. â€œWell do this and this will work, and this is the half ass reason weâ€™ll expand on later but first you have to understand how to do this not knowing why it works to understand why it worksâ€ my mind exploded and gave up. I remember in high school i was in a extracurricular where I was the aerospace officer, aka every month Iâ€™d have to give presentation on aerospace that would keep the focus of 12-18 olds, as a 16 year old myself, one of my lectures I naturally wanted to explain why planes fly- Bernoulliâ€™s principle- as we had been explained by chapter after chapter of this clubâ€™s books as well as my community college engineering 101 courses. Well imagine my angst to find that Bernoulliâ€™s principle was not the entire to story to why an airfoil generates lift- far from it and actually led to a wormhole of physicists arguing amongst themselves that left my calc 1 brain scrambled. I know I canâ€™t know everything, but I hate being taught blind. Tell me what Iâ€™m learning and why. Donâ€™t tell me one thing as a lie to later say â€œgotchaâ€ why? Cause I have x notes Iâ€™ve memorized in my consciousness now at this point to the point I dream of solving equations due to how much you make me study for these courses and formulas to solve equations and â€œgotchaâ€ throws that all in the water- back to square one- no but Iâ€™m going to hold on salvage said pastâ€¦ yeah made it half way through Biomed engineering before my health declined and equations now fill me with a sense of dread because who the hell knows what this specific professor for this specific unit of this course means by â€œeâ€ or â€œxâ€ in his notes, I have no clue. What is up and what is down? No clue. But one things for sure, no thank you. Back to square one- what is my purpose and what should I do? When you said itâ€™s like a compass- it resonated with me. I imagined Jack Sparrow and his compass pointing to him to whatever he truly desires- blindly- and oh how I deeply wish for such simplicity because I havenâ€™t the slightest clue- the compass is broken as it spins across the dial and Jack looks at it puzzled at his confliction- so Iâ€™ll blindly tell myself to go south, but maybe itâ€™s East or West? Not the slightest clue.

@hubermanlab, thank you for hosting Mr. Greene, and after a tbi in mma and a car accident last year, i've had a wonderful arduous journey exploring rewiring my brain with some nifty yale students and i feel that, in my study of social science and engineering, there are individuals such as myself that survive moreso through the mammalian brain and to be engaged in modern society at times, I know, is a very unique experience, understand that my space in time feels to me, to be that more of a shark in water, than an average person trying to just live his life.   skateboarding, mountain biking, poetry, painting, and various other nuanced practices, and i feel like a strange modern samurai, well, moreso a ronin, but i use the practice of "art" to get into the flow state, though i'm not the best at any of it, after multiple brain injuries, i myself, have gone through multiple changes, almost like puberty again, its weird.   i see student doctors from yale n stuff and i've always wanted to be one, like, i used to like sociology but the grander concept of Social Engineer is just a wild concept to me, so much so, i've dedicated almost a decade fighting the darkness of traumas and not becoming a statistic unless its for a positive reason, to figure out exactly what my purpose is and to fulfill it.   The way the two of you spoke of the expansion of our consciousness through that internal dialogue that can generate a flow state, its hard at times, but achieving it through a singular means, to me, was vary narrow minded, so i attempted multiples of activities simultaneously to activate the flow state to try and rewire the neurological damage that has occured in my brain.  That and mushrooms.   It has been working. I also try to teach people how to use their minds properly and it gets me in trouble sometimes.   Time is a lie and i think those who think not of it are the ones that live forever.   Where did time come from? the compass, not the sun dial, though we knew the sun and weather changed yet we did not yet know of "time." To percieve time is different than to exist in time.

Video Summary:  Robert Greene discusses finding and pursuing one's purpose, starting with childhood experiences and inner voices. He emphasizes cutting out distractions and understanding the impact of external influences. Greene highlights positive emotional experiences, self-observation, nutrition, and the Sublime's role in the journey. He discusses power dynamics and maintaining authenticity and integrity for success and personal growth.  Greene also explores vulnerability as a form of intelligence and power dynamics in sexual relationships. He talks about love and connection as biological desires, the negative effects of hookup culture and technology, and the importance of self-awareness and communication. He stresses the importance of non-verbal communication and social skills, advocating for in-person interactions over virtual ones.  Greene shares personal experiences with anxiety, stroke, and gratitude, emphasizing the importance of mental faculties and appreciating life's simple moments. He introduces the concept of "death ground" from his book, where extreme focus and energy are required to overcome obstacles. Finally, Greene invites listeners to join his monthly neural network newsletter for science-related topics.

Imagine Albert Einstein advertising mattresses for money. It would certainly make me perceive Einstein differently and lower my respect and esteem for him to some degree. Andrew Huberman is a prominent figure on YouTube and in popular science, widely respected in his field. Assuming that he earns enough income from YouTube and his position at Stanford to afford a decent life, I wonder if he could consider being more judicious with advertisements. I know someone that is fantastic typist. She is a legal secretary that can type 250 + words per minute and here is why.  She loved her father immensely as a child but he worked very hard and was seldom home. One day he gifted her a typewriter (the old school kind) and she very quickly learned to type at incredible speeds as a child. The love she had for her father and the gift he bestowed upon her made her into that phenomenal  typist she is today.  Her gift to her father was to master the gift he had given her in a show of appreciation.

I get the impression that "purpose" is just a craving that your intellect has signed off on as being socially worthwhile. Craving is largely a function of dopamine scheduling and habituating, which Andrew talks about on other podcasts. The people Robert talks about (Da Vinci, Mozart, Darwin, Einstein) were able to align their desires with social acceptance. But not everyone can be Da Vinci, Mozart, Darwin, or Einstein. It would be a disaster for the species if people were unable to find purpose in the more mundane pursuits that make societies work.
The human brain is definitely wired for one thing:    MORE.

the most important distinction to make here is that finding that authentic seed of inner personal bliss is totally different than what social media and the outside world trains us to try to be above and special and unique - those endeavours which can literally make one ill.  So this is about personal inner joy and bliss. In fact what the world considers ordinary can be totally delightful and exquisite in one's inner experience.

Start breathing. Every time a thought (or a "problem") pops up in your mind that wants to grab your attention: start breathing. Finally, your Inner Voice, the real You, will thank you for giving You the time for finally letting You speak. It takes some discipline, NOT effort NOR willpower. Just gentle kindness to stop the chatter in your mind. This looks a lot like the "monkey mind." The only (...) thing to overcome is to stop trusting all the well-meant and not so well-meant "voices" from the outside world (especially between 0 and ~7 years) and relearn to trust on your own breath and spirit (in many languages they are the same word or have the same roots). After a little while you will (re)discover mindfulness on your own! It's worth the try, and many will experience bliss and euphoria. Here lies one of the probably, biggest trap: you'll want that experience again, and you risk "forcing yourself" into this state. My advice: just breathe through it. You cannot get the past back anyway. There is only the present. Which you will learn in a non-analytic way rather quick. Good luck!

I remember reading The Art of Seduction when I was 21 and being unsure, as a young woman, if this book was written with good or nefarious intentions. (Mind you, The Game was very popular among college boys at the time.) Still, I was fully absorbed. When I read The Art of Power years later, I asked myself what type of character this is written for, but approached it less on-guard. Now as I approach 40, I see the complete amorality of these insights on human interactions and the human ego. No one tells you about these dynamics unless you are lucky to have parents or mentors who are there to guide you; and often their advice is colored by personal experience.  Thank you, Robert, for books like these and Mastery, which present observations and analyses without judgement. Theyâ€™ve given me so much to consider throughout the years

I have always known exactly why I came here. Since I was a toddler I had to be around horses. In those days we lived on the outskirts of a city and a lot of people still used horses for deliveries (milk, bread etc).. Even though my family wasn't horsey at all I grew up keeping and following my dream... Sometimes it came at a cost of huge disputes with my parents who told me I was crazy...it sure wasn't easy but I have managed....for the past 54 years I have been riding, training and eventually also teaching dressage. Owned my own horses as soon as I started to work. Rescued many horse from slaughter by re-training them, had a very nice national and international competition career, owned my own stud for 8 years and still now at 65 have 2 beautiful stallions. I have 2 diplomas and speak 6 languages.Whatever I set my mind to I achieve because I want it. Simple. Hopefully this inspires other people.

CONGRATULATIONS ğŸ‰ You sound like my 30 yr daughter! I put her on a pony at 9 mos old at our local Sunday Farmers Market. That was all she wrote! This was a weekly occurrence, and by far, my best disciplinary tool while she grew up. Iâ€™ve got pictures of her at every stage of her riding career. She became a champion hunter jumper, and to this day, I still feel like my heart will stop each time I watch her round a corner as she looks to where her course jumps begin. Watching her command her very large horse with ease over these high, scary (to me, not her) HIGH jumps is a sight to behold. Little did I know at the time that, like you, horses were in her blood. Thank goodness I didnâ€™t try to stop her. I am not a horse person myself, nor were we a horse family per se, but I got on board quickly, trying to figure out how we could do it. Itâ€™s a criminally expensive sport, and I sacrificed a lot to make it happen for her. I mucked stalls, cleaned tack, fed and turned out horses, all so we could offset her boarding fees. Also like you, she has switched to Dressage, a beautiful dance between rider and horse. She also works full time as an engineer in Tech. She works remotely, and sheâ€™s at  the barn at 5:30am to ride and train for several hours before she starts work. She often goes to the barn again later in the day. I may have missed it but I was hoping to hear a clear definition of â€œpurposeâ€. When I hear the word purpose, I think of usefulness, as in the purpose of a hammer is to drive nails. I have wondered if the notion of human beings having purpose may have its roots in religion. In Christianity, for instance, the ultimate purpose of a believer is to execute the will of God. The Bible represents the will of God and so living a life according to Godâ€™s commandments is the purpose of a Christian.   If you are not a believer, then you have to come up some other way to define purpose. A non-religious approach to defining purpose is living within an ethical framework (either self-developed or adopted) that enables you to live harmoniously with other human beings(society) and nature. This purpose becomes more proactive and directed if you actively seek to avoid harm to society and nature as well as pursue ways in which you can contribute positively to both society and nature.   The key in both the above cases is that there is a moral or ethical framework that sets guidelines for living. So, your purpose within this context is how you go about contributing positively to society and nature. At least that is how I see it.   I enjoyed how this discussion focused on how to find a purpose that excites you while offering the least amount of friction to your nature.

The belief in some sort of individual reincarnative process is so common in pre-Abrahamic societies globally it makes me wonder if reincarnation is an adaptive belief to overcome death anxiety. Implemented in such a way that it balances the sacred nature of the individual life-instance (yielding fertile ontological conditions for the conception of human rights, individual liberty etc) with the promise of a continued life experience after death, it needs only a multi-incarnative scorecard (karma and similar concepts/memetic structures) to stabilize society and hedge individual ego.  I suspect that a millenia and a half of indoctrination into various abrahamic operating systems has amplified death anxiety. Our original hyperlocal stable belief systems addressed it, but christianity supplanted it with it's fixation on worshipping an ethnic tulpa. It made us cognitively serfs of an imaginary friend to whom we had assigned write/read control over our sense of reality. It performed its designed function of wealth transfer, but at the cost of half the worlds psyche. Once the bulk of the zeitgeist deleted the nonsense of christianity we failed to build a system of cognitive tools capable of addressing the problems it suppressed/denied. Instead we fell into simply doing all of the things it said were bad, forgetting that the reason it was such an effective system of control was it's practice of fusing truths with ethnic nonsense. It infantalized us, and our hard turn to addressing spiritual problems purely via biology is I think in part a product of the fact that we now distrust our capacity to create our own useful metaphors/belief systems. Nihilism creates obedience to power, religion creates obedience to power. An ontology in which one believes they reincarnate, but with a burden or boost based on how they treated others in prior lives creates the conditions for resistance to injustice. Choosing to believe that we are some kind of sacrificial natal cells in a universal egg hatching a technocratic multi-system-spanning borglike society (which is a disturbingly common belief, and one that only serves the select few who funded it into being) is just that: a belief. A faith set against an unknown future. Why choose a metaphor with such self-destructive consequences when much more meaningful and socially beneficial metaphors exist?Â A neurological mechanism for free will has yet to be discovered, but actually using that as your ontology is not useful for anything.   The metaphor I choose is this: We are sentient pieces of the universe, observing ourselves. I am made of previous patterns, remixed and adapted for the current spacetime. I accrue observations and experiences which change me. When I reabsorb into my outer self (the universe), those memories and the pattern of my biology will be shed, a relic to history. Another form like me will arise. It will be adapted to its world. I will be that thing, as I was before and I am now. Conveniently I am spawning all the time. I've been born millions more times in the span of time since this primate chassis spawned. Each one is a holy thing, a pattern just as important as the pattern I am, but no more. It is my responsibility to maximize this pattern whilst helping other instances of me suffer less and become greater in those ways that I can. I must protect the integrity of this pattern as it was a huge investment on my part and the next time will lack some of the opportunities of this time. I am sovereign, I am eternal, but I am also mortal and there are those of me more powerful than I. There is no deity in the outer sense. The only "deity" capable of creation within the outerself of our universe is me, you, all other humans and probably some plasma nebula or mycelial mat that's gained consciousness somewhere. It's fascinating to ponder how reading micro expressions and genuine smiles can impact our connections with others. The rise of botox and its potential to inhibit natural facial motion does raise concerns about the depth of connection in human interactions. Have you noticed any difficulties in connecting with individuals whose facial expressions seem less natural due to botox usage?   It's interesting because I posed this question to many friends and family, and most of them are surprised and haven't thought of this. I feel like I may have a harder time connecting with someone whose face doesn't move naturally. Maybe this is due to my inability to read their micro expressions, which leaves me unwilling to be vulnerable? Just a thought.

I really appreciated so much of the insight presented here, particularly about the true expression of masculinity.. but i highly disagree with Mr. Greene's assessment of online dating. Its hard to meet people, especially as you get older and if you dont like to go to bars. Meeting people organically is obviously preferential but the reality is there are a lot of cool people out there who you will never meet because they wont come into contact with your friend group, or they dont like bars or parties, or the live out of your town or neighborhood, or for for myriad other reasons. Tinder etc is an excellent way to meet people who you would not otherwise naturally meet and i have many friends who have met their partners via the app. You get to assess the micro elements of their personality through their choice of words, how they engage in conversation, what they choose to talk about etc. then of course you encounter their energy when and if you first meet them. Going out costs time, money and energy. Tinder costs nothing and saves you a lot of these things, again especially if you are new to an area and dont want to meet someone at a bar ğŸ™

â¤â¤â¤  regarding the necessity and power of role models, all young creatures learn how to live, be and thrive in their environments by observing and emulating their parental units, litter mates and community members. It is an evolutionary process of survival.  Having been raised in a family system where there were six generations of incest and physical abuse (that I could trace), I did not have any functional, healthy role models that showed me how to become my highest and best self; expressing my interests, gifts and talents. As a survival mechanism, I retreated from the threat of my physical environment by escaping into books and movies.   And, it was in these beautiful worlds of stories that I discovered the possibility of a hopeful future.   It was from these incredible and vulnerable characters that I discovered my true self. These beautiful, loving, empowered role  models showed me the possibility of creating myself in their images.   Aubrey, I would love it if you would create a series of podcasts that explores movies as a source of heroic, stable, impactful characters from whom we can all learn how to live up to our potential as positive, creative beings. ğŸ˜Šâ¤  And wouldn't it be fun, to spend time with a few viewers who are living an active life wherein those characteristics and values gleaned from role models are being used in their personal lives?   Oooh, oooh, oooh, Aubrey! Have you thought about expanding your broadcast into a television series? Of course, you would have to have  influential editing and production control over each show.

â¤  when you were discussing non-sexual mounting, I remembered a pair of English bulldogs I once owned. They were brothers and best friends.   I was startled the first time I saw the littlest, and most adventurous brother, mounting his bigger brother.   At the time, it made me wonder about the existence of homosexual attraction in the animal kingdom.   However, as I look back, there was never any sexual intercourse involved.   It now makes sense to me that the more intelligent and risk-taking brothe was actually claiming his place as "top dog" in the relationship.

â¤â¤â¤ğŸ˜Š I am loving this conversation and am learning so many new concepts and clarifying truths that I instinctively knew as a child.   I stopped the video at the point where you are talking about power.  As a 68 year old grandmother of a five year old grandson, I have the privilege and joy of closely observing his daily development as a little adult in the making.   I've observed the necessity of a child feeling empowered and powerful in order to be their authentic and fearless self. We all need to feel SAFE in order to be fully immersed in the lessons and delights that our environment and experiences afford us moment by moment. And, it is in these moments that we grow mentally, emotionally, physically and spiritually.   In the last five years,  I've noticed that when my grandson plays with others, if there is a dispute over an accidental or purposeful injury (physical or emotional), the child who suffered the injury will strike out to inflict a similar injury. In watching these squabbles, I've noticed that it isn't about revenge, It is about regaining an equal status of power.  When the children are equally matched in power, the course of the play and the relationship settles into a pleasant and satisfying experience where each child feels good about themselves, the other, and their shared time together.

â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹Â @PurplePerinaiseÂ  I disagree that you need youth if your goal is anything other than making money but that's besides the point. You are talking about goals, OP is talking about their life's purpose.  Purpose is not a goal. There can be goals involved, but they're not the same thing. Purpose is something you do/something you live out in order to make the world around you a better place and OP is clearly doing that.  I think this is why the disconnect between your comments and the other perspectives in this thread. I sense that you are coming at it more from a career angle, hence "foundation for greatness" and goals. Pursuing greatness is about ego. Goals tend to be self-orientated, whereas purpose is more outward-facing. It's how people connect to something bigger than themselves - community, passing on wisdom learned through experience, raising other people up, nature... Ask yourself, what is the thing in life I care so much about that I want it to exist even after I am gone?  These are the things related to purpose. And because often life leads us down other paths (the career and goals we are told will make us happy), we can be delayed in finding our life's purpose. Often people come to it later in life and for that reason I'd say OP is right on time ğŸ™Œ  You can fulfill your life's purpose in one day, but hopefully you get longer...

Huberman talks a lot about dopamine and dopamine management.  I've thought that yes, that is a lens, and yes, it's accurate... but from a certain point of view.  A limited point of view.  What Greene is talking about regarding the sublime is very real and very true.  It is a thing that transcends what is apparently obvious and inescapable cause and effect when looking at brain chemistry and dopamine networks.  Although, I have to disagree a bit with Greene.  Many people experience the sublime from external sources.  The thing that is touched by these experiences is deeply internal.  Great art does it.  And despite what Greene said about drugs, many people have sublime experiences with drugs that are not on the order and cheapness of pornography.  I remember hearing and reading some quote by James Joyce defining art and pornography and comparing them.  Pornography disconnects you from your deeper self and inner truth, art connects you to it.  Both are external, but one is superficial and the other is deep.

I struggle to find the right words to convey how appreciative and thankful I am for all the wisdom shared in this episode. When i convinced myself I was content with dying and life by no means has anything left to offer but more pain and sorrow, after some time in this state of mind I would find myself in one of the most beautiful blissfully welcoming dream of what seemed to be paradise. It was this house with a Ferris wheel attached to the back side and a beautiful beach behind it. Inside the house it had thick white carpet, cool blue and grey color walls with white trim, some rooms empty and few had a single occupant seemingly sharing the same feelings as me and were waiting to leave. I stayed in the room i picked which had been a dream of mine to finally have some kind of stability. the room being perfect quenching my deepest desires and after running around with the other for awhile playing games sharing stories we were told by this handsome younger looking fella with a black button up and loosely worn white pants to come to the back it was time to get on the Ferris wheel. But before we did we all ran to the beach now standing adjacent to the house on the softest sand Iâ€™ve ever felt with a never ending sight of spotless white clouds encapsulating the area which had a baseball field shape and where I had been currently standing would be far left field. Gazing out into the ocean of clouds I felt weightless and sense of happiness transcended higher then what Iâ€™ve felt before. I hear a calling and turn to see the friend I had made running over to me she nice and extraordinarily beautiful. I headed towards her as she caught up and we began walking leaving footprints in the sand up to the house when I had gazed up at the Ferris wheel and noticed how gargantuan it was in size planting itâ€™s foundation into the sand it would connect to the house at the deck and rotate into the clouds above. Going back inside I visited the room one last time I had no belongings nor did anyone else all we had in common was a feeling of peace. Walking out the sliding glass doors onto the deck. It felt like a parking garage from the house to the Ferris wheel it was about 30 feet with an over hang so I couldnâ€™t see the top all I could see was the beach behind it  and the handsome young man awaiting to open the Ferris door. I causally walked towards him ready to go. So calm and relaxed in a way Iâ€™ve never experienced before I understood where I was going and if I chose to go Iâ€™d be leaving my body behind for ever. I canâ€™t explain in words the feeling of relief and joy i entered into just before getting on. Once I sat down and closed the door I got a phone call which woke me up trapping me once again in this physical body.

The problem is already that the technology is driving too many of us. Particularly with respect to AI. If it cannot have the same emotions as a human being, where is its actual "intelligence?" Apparently in the people that programmed it, not so much in the software itself. I don't think we can ever achieve true AI in the sense explained here by Robert Greene. Can it search databases in the blink of an eye? Sure. Can it write something wholly new or creative? No. The best it can do is draw from multiple sources and try to make the end product make sense to a human. Can it provide inspiration? I'm sure it can, but I don't believe anything we can make will have a true spark of  consciousness or or original creativity.  An AI learning is merely it recording more data to access when someone interfaces with it. It can be taught to respond certain ways, but will it actually learn from its environment without the intervention of trainers or external algorhithms? I doubt it. At the very least not until we've achieved encasing a series of quantum computers in the same space as a laptop.

Woah woah okay normally I love Hubermans ability to understand situations he has only studied yet seems to really understand....but I sincerely hope he is not being swayed by this guy's egocentric all knowing viewpoints. I grew up in an environment that intelligence, wanting to learn about everything and abstract ideas was let's say.....looked at as well strange and otherwise ignored. I was always an extremely gifted student in EVERYTHING except math...I know believe I may have a type of disorder that literally makes it difficult on a severely limited level to comprehend math. I liken it to the energy output those with issues in reading have. Anyway, alot of addiction and interpersonal issues and instability was a constant. ğŸ“š Robert Greene's books explore the interaction between the psychology of self-exploration and human interaction, rooted in history and modern culture, providing practical tools for pursuing one's purpose. ğŸŒ± Finding your purpose is like having an internal radar that guides your best decisions and gives your life direction and energy. ğŸ§  When you figure out that primal inclination that's inside of you, then you have the energy to be disciplined and go through boring tasks to learn at a faster rate because you're emotionally engaged. ğŸŒ± Finding your unique purpose may take time, but it's never too late to start the process of self-discovery and dig deep to uncover your true path. ğŸŒ± Finding your unique purpose is about activating a visceral, emotional, and physical feeling within you, not just an intellectual pursuit. ğŸ§  The excitement and delight in pursuing our purpose is visceral and ultimately requires action to transmute it into something real. ğŸ§  The human brain is wired for transcendental experiences that take us out of the narrow realm we live in, allowing us to feel connected to something larger. ğŸŒŒ The real Sublime comes from within, not from external sources like drugs, alcohol, or shopping. Power dynamics and influence ğŸ’ª Power is deeply wired in us to want a degree of control over our environment and immediate events, compelling us to act in certain ways to influence others. ğŸ­ Learning the subtle dynamics of power is extremely essential because we're a social animal. ğŸ§  Connecting to mastery and finding your life's purpose is about finding where you belong and proving yourself, not about physical power or a sense of inferiority. Creativity and the human brain ğŸ˜“ Robert Greene's creative process is 95% pain and only 2.5% ecstasy, showing that creativity often involves a lot of inner turmoil and anxiety. ğŸ˜… Robert Greene's process for writing involves a lot of anxiety, but the feeling of accomplishment when finishing a chapter or a book is better than any kind of drug experience. ğŸ§  We worship technology as our new religion, but we should be worshiping the human brain, the most complex piece of matter in the universe.

Necessity is the mother of invention. So, create necessity in your life. Get rid of the tv. Then it becomes necessary to find other entertainment, for instance. Make a rule that you turn your phone in airplane mode during walks. Own less clothing, and it becomes necessary to do your laundry. Observe what happens when you are in some sort of minor crisis, like running out of gas, with no phone. All the sudden you find yourself jogging 5 miles, asking for help; doing the necessary things. Create Necessity. Build it in through deadlines, exercises and games for your life. My best "dishes" are created with only what I have on hand -- no shopping, no list of ingredients -- just the bare necessities. ğŸ»

The sublime state that Robert Greene talks about early in the podcast and the out-of-body experience he talks about towards the end is amazing to imagine and perceive. I thought about myself as a little girl. I brought out old photo albums to jog my memory. Soon it came flooding over me. Babies. As my family has posted them to social media.  I am kneeling by the chrismas tree on chrismas morning,  My hair is perfect and I'm wearing a frilly 80's plaid nightgown. My arms are crossed and I'm pouting. Bottom  lip is all the way out. My brother posted it to social media; she didn't get the doll that pees; best caption Go! The comments are extremely funny. I learned what water sports are. LMAO What this podcast brought to light is that I was a maternity nurse for 8 years. It was a babydoll yes, but also the human body and how it works that I love.   Another funny story. My dad would buy me a small something I wanted if I got all A's. I had been wanting a book about the human body with these amazing drawings of all antomy.  I was 7, so my brother was 12. He ripped out all the "female" drawings. I was so mad, I told my mom and she giggled, that made me more mad. I asked where he was, she said getting out of hockey, but that had friend that was coming over. I then went and ripped all the "male" drawings out and taped them to his bedroom walls. He opens his door with his friend standing behind him and there are a penises, scrotums etc all over. My poor mother. She made me stand there while she told his friends mother. Who looked at me and said well maybe this book isn't for children. I responded with,  well it is now and walked away.

What an amazing interview. In some contexts (Only my opinion) I think Andrew came up with this naive perspective of life, for example in thinking about of how to fit within his group of friends. There is no hierarchy yes, but there is a clear fight for being the Alpha, and this fight is emotional, and political, and many people think they have to either fit in or fit in, no matter what, which I think Robert is trying to explain how this is just not true. I think it's a wiser game to say, "Well maybe I am this alpha or this beta or this other person who actually do not fit in, and that's ok". Then it's your job to create an environment that is positive in which you do fit. Otherwise life can become really painful trying to "fake" yourself into life. In my opinion it's more hurtful trying to fit in where you don't, contrary to opening up and seeing there is other ways of impacting society in a positive way and connecting with other human beings where you fit. It's beautiful and profoundly self assuring to just let go, and go find your way.

I really am enjoying this conversation and Iâ€™ve found myself laughing and smiling at several points. My biggest criticism of it revolves around a concept that I will call unconscious gendered perception of universal reality. Itâ€™s clear that much of his thinking relies heavily on his embodied male experience in this world. Iâ€™m not sure if heâ€™s aware of this or if he is just not making a point of it out loud but at many points in the discussion he seems to generalize behavior based on gender constructs that are more common in this western culture and within historically male centric research and literature of essentialism between the binary genders carved into western cultures. He seems to yearn for a simplistic definition of what it means to be one sort of human being or another and yet one of the first things he elaborates on as crucial for self actualization is the unique individualism of every human from all others. He must be unaware of this blurring between his own personal experience and his sense of rightness for defining the behaviors of others, especially in a gendered way. I have a problem with his definition and use of the word seduction. There is a long long metaphorical association of this particular word with a perceived dangerous manipulation of men by women. But he also seems to be using it as a metaphor for how those who lack physical power or even inanimate objects or intellectual pursuits can become seductive. Thereâ€™s a difference here in what is being said and yet he doesnâ€™t highlight this; from everything else heâ€™s just spoken about I donâ€™t think heâ€™s aware that heâ€™s associating the word both with negative intent but also as a beneficial instinctive behavior.  Again the female seduction is from a very specific intellectual male cultural perspective. But he doesnâ€™t seem to understand this. This is one of those conversations that I wish I could have been a part of. What he is saying is very important but I am concerned about his assumption of authority on aspects of unlived experience he states as facts.

The sublime, the liminal, the subaltern; these are all descriptions of the spaces that we cannot occupy in any direct sense but which we all pass through at some point in our lives. Some of us live closer to these spaces than others but the majority of the time we live in the profane or non sacred spaces of our ordinary lives. The more we can recognize our proximity to these moments of passage the better we are able to handle them and also the greater the chances become for inspiration and growth. The idea of killing time is the unconscious feeling between these moments of transcendent experience. I think instead of humans attempting to murder time, perhaps instead we are seeing the process of a toxic mimicking. Those who are lost within any addiction or post trauma behavior that negatively impacts them are essentially attempting to escape the painful and dull profanity of a life which has not allowed them to experience or benefit from these moments. We are both afraid of these experiences and also deeply yearn for them. We use religion or other forms of containment in order to make them less scary and yet in this way we end up caging and taming the essential qualities of wildness, mystery, and we often end up further alienating ourselves from ever passing through these moments consciously. When we learn to accept the fact that there are spaces where transformation becomes possible we are more likely to enjoy life and we feel less insecure about change, whether internal or otherwise. It remains mysterious and uncomfortable however instead of fear or denial we develop our connection with everyone and the compassion necessary for self acceptance and self awareness. From this perspective we can recognize places where growth is possible and the sublime becomes more easy to recognize when it is occurring.

I had this idea of "evolved" consciousness in that some people through brain hardwiring (genetics = hyperlimbic i.e. increased emotional sensitivity), life events and brain re-wiring through mindfulness/awareness, physical and mental training can level up their brain capacity to see past the hierarchal "less evolved" brain to that more lateral/compassion based/ego-less awareness. The extra sensitivity of the hardwiring with the added training of the limbic response from a hyjacked emotional reactive brain to one that can pause, reflect and respond allows for the human to see a different dimension and expands the field of awareness to an evolved state of being. Did I make that up or is this type of lymbic brain evolution being seen in research studies? I work as a teacher and I am fascinated by the effects of trauma on the learning brain and trying to work with ways to break the stress cycle so they can learn (using exercise/connection/self-compassion) and the key to being an effective educator is being able to regulate our own emotions when a student gets triggered (which happens often) and to respond in a compassionate way. My work in training my own ability to sit in the discomfort of others and not taking it personally has evolved my own ability to see through a lot of the bullshit that we create in our own minds and given me a better ability to respond with compassion and equality/equinimity instead of the less evolved emotional egoic reaction. Not sure if anyone will ever read this but I just needed to write it somewhere. Not sure how to label it so wanted to ask if you connect this to anything in neuroscience research right now. Loved this episode and the topic. At a point in my life where I am seriously exploring what my purpose is and how I can build a life that is authentic to me. Contemplating my purpose at many points in my life, I'm learning a few things: 1) purpose around something is felt and experienced and iterated, and mastery is built gradually - this was a learning for me because I fell into a mental trap at one point, thinking if something is part of my purpose there's essentially very little learning before mastery, 2) internalized beliefs that are not truly mine prevented me from seeing what I really want to pursue, 3) purpose could be a combination of multiple things that are aligned with you, 4) it's a difficult journey when you have not yet built the credibility or mastery around your purpose - but it's worth the feeling of mental clarity and intrinsic motivation derived from it, 5) my life is not linear, and because of things like self-doubt and trauma, I needed to practice a lot of patience and compassion towards myself. Right now I feel really strongly about developing personal health companion technologies as it seems like just the right amount of intellectual challenge and passion towards the natural interests that I have (social justice, psychology, systems-level technologies like AI). Let's see where this takes me!

Â @krmccarrellÂ  Understanding that the resources you have mean everything when you've got the clear wits about you the sharp understanding of where you are in life, you know the direction you feel you must travel, You've done all the heavy lifting and i'm truly proud of you for that. Identifying the problem is the most difficult or unlikely part of the process, but the first and most critical step in solving any problem, the issue is that our brain is wired to look for problems, when you recall memories your unfelt emotions will resurface in your short term memory, the brains screen so to speak. You have to turn to the family members you don't wish to tell the truth to and say what you are so afraid to say, what your child self did not feel safe to do, you are an adult now and you can speak the truth and experience fear not as the identification of danger but as a grateful mechanism we have to understand the roadsigns at the corner of danger and safety, the awareness that you are afraid, and the feeling, is good because it means you know what you are afraid of, it means you know which way you are afraid of and know you can begin to accurately assess which risks you know you should take and sometimes asking for help feels like it's gonna hurt you because the way that you've organized everything in your head from when you were a child on that fast learning curve was to stay silent because you were vulnerable, the brave thing now might be knocking on a neighbors door and asking: "can i tell you my story" calling your children and asking them to listen, calling any parents you have and telling them what happened, honestly, i'm gonna be real about I think calling the police would allow you to put the people who hurt you in prison, and i know it sounds dramatic or like an oversell of what happened to you but all of the people who abused you belong in prison and an abuser that moves on continues to offend in other places. If you do not feel safe, you need to shift towards safety, when you don't know which way safe is because fear is too loud, like people with pain disorders who feel pain that doesn't help them identify pain some of your fear doesn't help you identify danger anymore, what's important from here is going to banks, going to doctors going to therapists going to physios speaking to experts who you can trust institutionally, reach out to AS MANY PEOPLE AS YOU NEED TO FEEL SAFE, ask the woman walking down your block for her number, find the nearest theater, connect with your local library, call people call people call people right? If you feel comfortable you can check in here and let me know how you are doing and if you were able to put your abuser in prison, You can feel guilt that's okay, But that guilt is his for abusing you, and we no longer make deals with terrorists, therer's no deal you need to make and you can take care of yourself, you can say goodbye to everyone you love and be okay, you can live solo, and be alright you can have your freedom you are protected in our constitution, this is where you form connections. You can share the music you like with ANYONE and it is always a treat, impose your SELF on other people, show them who you are and CRY cry your eyes out because of the circumstance and use your experiences to bond with others in a healthy way, it's important that you form really strong connections and establish trust with as many people as possible, talking laughing crying, angry, tired, hunger, sadness, sit with people and talk, you have always been in side of you

I find the term â€˜broken homesâ€™ incredibly old fashioned and extremely offensive to those single parents who make the decision to raise their children alone for a variety of valid and responsible reasons. There are millions of adults from one parent families all over the world who are perfectly well balanced, happy and thriving human beings.  People ask themselves â€˜who am I?â€™ regardless of their background, race, orientation or how many parents they have and those who continue to use this outdated term are sadly continuing and enforcing a stigma attached to children/adults from one parent families - implying they are somehow the weaker, less privileged of society.   Many parents who stay together despite having various serious issues raise dysfunctional, emotionally retarded and unhappy children and do more harm to them than making the brave decision to break up and spare their kids years of more misery which inevitably will develop into emotional instability/mental health problems as adults.   Yet do we attach the same debilitating label to them? No.

@robertgreeneofficial @andrew huberman When you two got to the part of social media ("sm") and reacting (usually in outrage) to sm content, I realized that Andrew and his guests are speaking to the sm crowd, and not necesarily Andrew's audience. I wish to note two points:  (1) The sm crowd is not representative of the population; they are a subgroup; and  (2) Those with some degree of career autonomy &/or financial security (i.e. Andrew's guests) assume that others are more concerned with self-actualization than they actually are. I would venture to say many more people are just trying to stay on the center of the treadmill, and maybe muster the power to get to the front of it.   Because people with a public persona tend to communicate to masses/followers on sm, they seem to lose sight of the (lack of) importance of sm in the lives of others. this is super interesting but I do have 3 areas where I would like to see a bit more science and a bit less opinion: 1. music taste or overlap is honestly irrelevant in a respectful relationship - my husband and I have an excellent 30 year long and counting, relationship that has extremely minor overlap of music taste. We don't impose our taste on each other and we don't need the other person to validate us by liking what we like( or pretending to do so). Where we meet is in our values and that is the most basic thing - as Dr Conti told us so well and clearly. PS my first husband and I had stongly overlapping music taste, but not values it turned out.  2. the non verbal communication 'reading ' of people is deeply flawed and we need to be careful. As your esteemed guest Dr Feldman Barrett pointed out, if you don't know the person and  therefore cannot use the existing data to effectively engage the pattern recognition engine that is the brain, you have alot of chance of just being massively wrong. Build the data before you make judgements - the brain is extremely good at taking shortcuts and those shortcuts are not necessarily beneficial (Robert Cialdini - Influence -  provides great examples of the good and bad sides of this) If someone doesn't immediately look delighted to see you maybe they were thinking about their sick mother before they switch on their 'game face' - the examples provided were deeply flawed  3. AI - for heavens sake - can we pull this out of the narrow focus of chatGPT esque, 2001 Hal opinion. AI is a massive positive tool for predictive maintenance, supply chain efficiency, massively improving efficiency and effective use of large data sets for incredibly improved outcomes -  like diagnosing breast cancer, for example. Can we please elevate the AI discussion? There is a much better, bigger discussion to have

I would like to THANK YOU BOTH Robert & Andrew for creating this harmonious discussion. Watching this podcast has been the most internally satisfactory experience I have had in what feel like FOREVER!! There are SO many threads to follow and explore here,  so Iâ€™ll kindly pull just one of them to share with you both as a HUGE & humble gesture of gratitude for all the courageous work you both do.  So. .  . I suffered a very severe TBI last April, which is how I came upon hubermanlabs (a desperate attempt to understand what I was experiencing and why there was such a serious lack supports & treatment options available!)  . . ..which btw this entire episode is extremely relevant to in a number of ways, both for the information that was provided but also for the information that was NOT provided. That said, I realize that the psychological dynamics within our precious nature of the human experience is SO very subjective & way too vast for one single discussion however, I would have LOVED to have heard â€œmoreâ€ surrounding how people with diminished capacities or limited abilities can work towards navigating these social dynamics. (While still gracious for the touch downs that were provided) I only offer that feedback because of the absolutely eloquent delivery of information provided here. I sincerely hope that Mr.Greene comes back for another flawless journey when his new book is released!Â    OKAY! Onto the â€œâ€˜threadâ€ğŸ¤ª I very much enjoyed the definition that was discussed on the feeling of â€œâ€˜sublimeâ€. I think that is most likely the main concept that enabled me to really grasp onto the perspectives being provided and understand them in relation to my own experiences and position, (which I have to say was exhilarating; itâ€™s likely been over 6 months since I've experienced that kind of cognitive functioning) The definition of what & where sublime is allowed me to locate and then understand the feelings of what it is exactly like to suffer with TBI. I can confidently say that living with TBI is literally like being pushed out of the â­• inherent subliminal zone and no one is throwing you a life saver or lending a hand or igniting a flare for you to find your way back OR even just shouting words of encouragement for that matter. I havenâ€™t come to understand the exact mechanics of this yet, whether itâ€™s lack of knowledge, money or respect BUT I have to say that the huberman lab has been a VERY BRIGHT LIGHT!  . . . .and itâ€™s extremely comforting to know the general direction in which Iâ€™m supposed to be going . . to said zone!!  SO AGAIN, THANK YOU SO MUCH! (first time sharing more then a thumb or a reduction of opinion, so I hope that it is useful to you, at least in some small way or form.) ğŸ™ğŸ»  P.S. I do have a number of ideas for topics and research if you are interested in hearing them?    P.P.S. My favourite word from this episode is for sure â€œ visceralâ€ especially when it comes to the nature of TBI and social acceptance. Ive found myself trying to accept my loss of identity/purpose and know thy â€œnewâ€ self in the best way that I can but it truly is a deeply rooted and basic NEED to be a part of the whole!  Despite any self guided ownership of existing outside that whole, it is still very much like a splinter in your entire being  . .  ..and everyone knows splinters suck!! ğŸ™Š  Thanks also to whoever takes the time to read what I have shared as well. Most of my youth and most of my life I've enjoyed organizing information. I had over 80 notebooks, fully written in by age 15. Mostly journaling, wisdom, Bible verses, mathematics, and sports statistics (I took by hand stats from my Tecmo Football and Baseball games).   This is very much like CS Lewis' thoughts that you need to find the things you enjoyed as a child. He credits this with his writing which led to the Chronicles of Narnia.   â€œCritics who treat 'adult' as a term of approval, instead of as a merely descriptive term, cannot be adult themselves. To be concerned about being grown up, to admire the grown up because it is grown up, to blush at the suspicion of being childish; these things are the marks of childhood and adolescence. And in childhood and adolescence they are, in moderation, healthy symptoms. Young things ought to want to grow. But to carry on into middle life or even into early manhood this concern about being adult is a mark of really arrested development. When I was ten, I read fairy tales in secret and would have been ashamed if I had been found doing so. Now that I am fifty I read them openly. When I became a man I put away childish things, including the fear of childishness and the desire to be very grown up.â€

Dear Andrew, thank you for the excellent episode.  I think Robert Greene is truly insightful.  I do ask that you clear up the false claim that Sigmund Freud had sexual relations with his patients.  This misinformation likely comes from a rumor started by Wilhelm Reich, a disgraced rival psychoanalytic theorist. Not only did Freud never have sex with any of his patients, he wrote a paper called "Observations on Transference-Love" in which he warns clinicians of the perils of getting involved in erotic relationships with patients.  As a psychoanalyst, I believe an ethical adherence to physical abstinence is absolutely essential to our practice.  Please consider having a psychoanalyst on your show.   Covering topics such as how mind relates to brain, the convergence of psychoanalytic and neurological theories of dreams, and how psychoanalytic discourse relates to the objective sciences would would be truly engaging.

Gardiner's Ideas on EQ, multiple intelligences etc have never been scientifically substantiated.  He basically wrote a pop sci book and put forth a hypothesis and it's never been tested. 38 here. For the past nine years, Iâ€™ve carried a deep sense of dread, feeling like Iâ€™ve wasted my life without making real progress, despite a genuine desire for change. This feeling has been with me since my mid-20s to some extent. It sounds clichÃ©, but it truly is never too late to make a change. What worked for me was setting aside just 25 minutes each day to focus on a new skill I was passionate about.   Whether it's a career shift or a hobby-- the key is committing fully, even if itâ€™s just 15 minutes of focused effort. The momentum builds when you can see the progress (no matter how small), and that drives you forward (it pulls you, it doesn't take long for the 25 minutes to go from work to enjoyment, The small obstacles become easier to overcome, and eventually, it feels almost effortless. You couldn't stop, even if you wanted to (and i'm not someone that has an easy time focusing, i'm not particularly intelligent or conciousencitous, it take me time to learn a new concept but it really does get considerably easier the more you do it, it's kind of amazing.  Start small and structured, then refine as you go. Set short-term goalsâ€”really short term. For example, watch the first five minutes of a course you're interested in, jot down your thoughts, and check it off your list. Then, set a reminder for tomorrow to start the first exercise. But itâ€™s crucial to remember that watching a video isnâ€™t the same as applying what youâ€™re learning. The real progress comes when you use the material in a small projectâ€”it sticks better that way. YouTube is fine for sparking ideas, but use it sparingly.  Just as important, donâ€™t be too hard on yourself. Focus on consistent, intentional progress. Over time, it will feel more natural. If you drift off course or spend a week heading in the wrong direction, take a moment to realign with what matters. And donâ€™t think of â€˜goalsâ€™ as distant trophiesâ€”your goal today is simply to focus on the one thing that helps you spend more time on what you're passionate about. Keep it simple and consistent, and accept that youâ€™ll get off track sometimes. When that happens, gently guide yourself back.  Also, I think you should pick up Marcus Aurelius' Meditations it's like my bible, when i'm caught up in trivial matters or lifes stresses it realigns my thoughts with what's important. You donâ€™t need to read it cover to cover. Just flip to a random page, read a passage or two, and I think you'll find it helps you focus on what truly matters to you...  wish I could convey it more clearly but that's some of what I noticed when I slowed down and really focused on one task at a time. and just to add, i'm not very intelligent, it takes me more time than most to learn a new skill or concept but it gets so much easier in a very short time, there's always the next point of stagnation but even those get easier or you can deal with them better and you're not as demoralised when you don't get something straight away. It's stuff I heard when I was young, everyone said it and I thought I was listening and understanding but I certainly didn't apply it

Try not to focus on your age per se, however what you have learned and what works, what does not. Time past is gone, the future not guaranteed. Today is the day to take that step, and the next. Some days small steps, some big, however moving forward is what matters with a system or plan.

This was a great conversation. This is precisely what many  people are struggling with.  Personally, i think human civilization, as we know it, will never return. As Mr. Huberman said, modern technology has hijacked our reward system and it has altered our definition of "normal."  It's very difficult to connect with people emotionally. I am not claiming it's impossible but it's near impossible.  It's quite sad. There are a lot of layers to our changing humanity. With AI on the verge of completely scrambling everything we've ever know to be true, dependable and lucrative, we are standing at a precipice. Some know this but the majority have no idea what is about to happen.  There is no pollyanna outlook. Too many people are struggling just to pay rent, figure out how to make a living, etc.   If you are wealthy, you are disconnected from the deep panic washing over millions of people. When life is always about just getting by, people begin to ask : "What's the point in working hard when there's no end in sight?"  History teaches us that all great civilizations fall. Our flaw has been that we regard ourselves to be too intelligent to make the mistakes of our dumb ancestors. Our hubris blinds us to our inevitable demise.   We live in a world where toxic positivity is rewarded and admired. Few people want to hear the truth, and when they hear it, they dismiss it or ignore it.  This time, we can't go back.
