So I'm half way through this and TWO key points I agree hugely on is: 1. Being vulnerable - reason being I am an intelligent woman and yet, I have been transgressed by domestic, sexual and emotional abuse. And then I met the love of my life and then, just six months ago, he took his own life. And then yet, I allowed myself to be vulnerable again and now am with a man who I am in equality with, completely safe and we are open about EVERYTHING and that has made us both more at peace, not looking to power plays and joyful than I ever could have imagined six months ago.  2. The art of ignoring - as mentioned, my wonderful husband took his life, but a big part of it was that every day, he would be so upset and angry about the injustices in the world. That, on that final night, he continued to tell me that the world was too much and that he wanted to fix it all, which I of course outlined was a fantasy and sadly not possible for him or any one person to undertake or be responsible for, and explained that he needed to just keep being the good in the world that keeps society going in an upward trajectory.   Sadly, people spend a lot of time subscribing to the "news" as it's all too readily available these days. I personally don't understand the reason why. I keep out of everyone's business generally, and I think I can attribute that to my positive outlook on life. Don't get me wrong, when my husband died, I wanted to aswell and almost did but then I allowed myself to be taken under a good man's wing, and here I am six months later, with a trip to Iceland booked for January (wish ne luck on that one) and the new man moving into my house. Yeah, I've had the same reservations flash across my mind that anyone in my circumstances would, but life is just too precious to allow that ego side in. Show up, honest, vulnerable, and with integrity, and the world will open up to you and give you a pure loving abundance. It's been a wild ride so far, and I'm only 34. Keep going.

Around 2:39:20 you talk about the comparison between the invention of the car vs AI. How walking/driving to the destination, and how that is fundamentally different (or not the same comparison ) than flying a helicopter to the top of mt Everest because the reward from reaching the destination is fundamentally different from the process or struggle to get somewhere.   I would disagree with you and say that both of them have/will alter how we view arriving at the destination/answer. If you have to walk 3 miles to the nearest restaurant, your relationship will change to arriving at that restaurant once you get a car and can drive that distance in a fraction of the time.   The invention of the calculator didn't make people more stupid, either did the internet. Cars or trains didn't ruin the destination. Yes we take the smaller things more for granted, but this technology is not going to make us more stupid or less curious as a species.

Andrew, thank you so much for all that you do! Neuroscience and understanding human behavior is a hobby of mine that consistently fascinates. Your work has been instrumental in advancing mine, and has helped me personally. I'm so grateful to you. I hope some day that we can meet and discuss the magnificent brain. In listening to you and Robert discuss his near death experience and what he was feeling at that moment, it brought up a question that has been nagging me for years, and that has left me completely bewildered. My Mother passed 3 years ago from lung disease that she got from house mold. She was an athlete, had never smoked once. She had been on oxygen for the last year of her life, and the last couple months was seeing a lot of hallucinations. The last week before she passed she had gone unconscious for 24 hours. Her vitals were all good, but she was not conscious. Hospice had told us to come say our goodbyes that day, that it was likely the end. But it wasn't. She woke up. Even in the massively declining mental state that she had been in for months, she remembered being unconscious those 24 hours, which blew my mind. She functioned normally the next few days and then she went into this unconscious state again. It was also about a 24 hour time period, and again, her vitals were all normal she was just completely unresponsive. It was about midnight and she had been unconscious that whole day, and the night before. Her caregiver, Sabastian (she was in an assisted living private home down the street from my home) was in her room straightening things with his back to her in the bed. She had called him Gary for the duration of her stay there because that was her boyfriend's name, and she could never remember Sabastian's name. In this moment, with his back to her, she awoke from her 24 hour unconscious state and said "Sabastian, I'm leaving now." He spun around to find her pointing out the window up towards the sky and looking up in the same direction. He said that she said something he couldn't make out, said my name and my brother's name, took 2 breathes and was gone. Being long time caregivers, he and his wife had lost numerous residents over the years, but neither had ever experienced anything like this. I arrived about 20 minutes after her passing, and Sabastian was still sobbing, completely shaken from how she had gone. I walked into her room to find her as he had described, her head turned, eyes still open, looking out the window up towards the dark sky. They had brought her hand back down to her side, preparing for Hospice to do a final check of vitals. My Dad and I have lovingly joked, that, "of course Mom went out this way." (She was a very controlling, disciplined individual, who needed things to be done her way.) But for anyone that has heard this story, it has absolutely blown their mind as well. I would love to know your thoughts, and @RobertGreeneOfficial as well. How could she have known she was going at that moment exactly? And how could she have remembered Sabastian's name? With the extreme lack of oxygen, how could her brain have had that kind of clarity? I've had a near death experience myself, that I survived and others didn't. It was a moment of enormous peace and clarity for me, even in the midst of such destruction. And immediately after I was forced to meditate for nearly an hour, laying on a mountain highway, blood pumping out of me, while my body shook uncontrollably trying to go into shock, as we all waited for paramedics to find us. I was able to keep myself conscious and focused, and alive. So I can truly understand how miraculous the brain can be, even at that level of trauma. But I wasn't lacking any oxygen. I had great health and full faculties going in, and meditation experience. My Mother had barely been able to carry on a conversation months prior. She was quite incoherent months leading up to her passing, and very childlike. She had always been a woman of high intelligence with a pretty incredible vocabulary. I'm sorry for the long post, but it seemed like an appropriate time and platform. I truly would love to hear any of your feedback to give me some sort of idea of what she could've been feeling, thinking, etc. Again, thank you for all that you are doing with your podcasts. You have changed my life more than you'll ever know!

I've had a small stroke myself and can vouch for the sudden, just...strange experience. There was just this sudden sensation that I liken to a pressure drop in my head and the realization that something was very, very, deeply wrong.   My sense of proportion got a little wonky and it was like a part of my fovea wasnt getting any signal and just started making shit up. Took me a minute to realize it was a blind spot and was bordered by a flashing zig-zag that slowly moved towards my peripheral vision.   Got out to my car and called my mom and she said it sounded like a migraine and i picked up some meds for that and woke up the next day with a brutal headache and went to work after slamming some coffee and ibuprofen.   The day after that, same thing happened, but that time I went numb in my arm and face and went to do a tongue check and within 24 hours I was told I had a dissected carotid artery. At 31.   I'm fully healed now, even if that artery is sealed at the base of my skull, so don't worry about me. Instead go watch something on stroke awareness and spend some serious time committing it to memory, because when it happens you need to be in go-mode at the drop.  This one is always a crowd pleaser. Best shown to someone with absolutely no warning.   https://youtu.be/ZDhzCIi0_wA

I've read and enjoyed Greene's work and because of your podcast I also bought and read Paul Conti's book Trauma and got a lot out of that too. But in your discussion with Conti you emphasised it had been important to you to find someone like him because he was a mental health practitioner with an iron-clad scientific background, which seems to mean, in this context, a medical one. Now with Greene you're talking to and promoting someone who doesn't have that at all, nor a psychological or psychotherapeutic training, knowledgeable as he is, yet is writing books that pertain to mental health.   I'm not saying you shouldn't, I'm saying doesn't this indicate the value you might get from people who, while not necessarily medically trained, are deeply knowledgeable about and trained in psychotherapeutic practice, an area that, as Conti already indicates, often requires even the medically trained to put aside their more rigid scientism? This is a field that is developing all the time, particularly in the area of so-called 'experiential' therapies like IFS and AEDP. In particular, I've found they offer brilliantly effective approachs achieving the kinds of objectives Greene lays out here around issues such as anxiety and self-knowledge â€“ approaches I genuinely think put almost everything else in the shade and deserve to be far better known. Tori Olds is an excellent source of information on these therapies on YouTube.

Dr. Huberman, I noticed what appears to be a discrepancy in your endorsed recommendations. I think my question can be summed up as should I sprint or should I jog at the end of my run? In your interview Maya, Sankar, she mentions that by making the final section of a hard task enjoyable, or less unenjoyable, one can decrease the aversion to said task. You seem to contradict this when you talk about, in your episode on tenacity and willpower, how adding a micro sucks at the end of a hard task increases tenacity and willpower.  Perhaps this contradiction lies in the definition of the goal of each of these protocols. Robert Greene's perspective on finding and achieving one's unique purpose is exceptionally insightful, offering a strategic and psychologically grounded approach to personal development. By emphasizing self-awareness, deliberate planning, and a continuous learning mindset, Greene encourages individuals to view their life's purpose as a dynamic journey rather than a fixed destination. What sets his insights apart is the seamless integration of historical wisdom and contemporary relevance, creating a nuanced guide that resonates across diverse experiences. Greene's work inspires a thoughtful and intentional approach to self-discovery, empowering individuals to navigate the complexities of life with strategic wisdom and adaptability.

The concept of  a life's purpose is something I think about a lot. I'm not sure that I believe that each person has a purpose and it's out job to find out what that is. I do think we all have gifts, abilities and other unique attributes that allow us to be successful at things we have an interest in and an a natural proclivity towards.  My entire life I thought and was told that my purpose is to be a wife and mother. Here I am at 40, single and childless wondering where I went wrong. How did I become someone that was undesirable to men? If that was my purpose and I never fulfilled it, what do I do now? How do I figure out what else I am supposed to do since my first option wasn't it? Each time I ponder this question, I keep circling back to the same conclusion that I should have been a wife and mother and I've just wasted my entire life because it's now too late for that to happen.  I bought Howard Gardner's % Frames of Mind and Robert Greene's Master, so maybe I will find something else once I have reach those books.  What does one do when they don't achieve their purpose?

This was such a great conversation but I do have a thought to add. In regards, to Mr. Greene's comments about young people not wanting the pain that comes from loving someone - therefore, they turn to more porn/hook-ups.  I could not agree more but I think it is the removal of pain that is causing the issue. I am a corporate learning architect and the mother of a 17 year old. My son told me a few years ago that he was one of two kids in his class who had to present a report in front of the class. I questioned him on this and he said all of the other kids had permission (due to anxiety) to not have to talk in front of the class. Around the same time, I started seeing college graduates coming into their first careers, joining my company showing similar concerns and often quitting to avoid certain painful  situations were being put in during their training orientation. So, now my thought - is it really that we have taken pain away from younger people in so many situations that now, even the fear of love it too painful to contemplate?

The 48 Laws was a great book for me. I felt lost a lot as a child and I really didn't have time for myself because I was busy translating papers for my family, so we could become citizens, while helping the family work in an under the table mattress business. I didn't really understand how to communicate how I feel or control certain situations until I was well in to my twenties. I was completely immersed and fascinated by structures and vessels of all kinds, but the scared little girl afraid of being deported, (while thinking girls can't do this) and poor took over me (even though at this point we're citizens) and pursued something that would make me certain money instead. I floundered through college because I was genuinely uninterested in what I was trying to pursue, but knew I loved making things. So here I am in my mid/late thirties completely starting over (it feels like). Also, I call finding your purpose "childlike wonder". Â @PyrrhonianÂ  " The last law of power is literally to remain fluid and follow no laws because he shows through the book that many laws can be contradicted and doing it and not doing it can both be advantageous "  This makes my point perfectly. What you have at the end of any given Green book is an absolute clusterfuck of ideas and strategies that may or may not work for any given person in any given situation, and may even be detrimental to some. With precisely no guidance whatsoever for how to determine which of these strategies are likely to be viable or productive and which are going to be counterproductive for you (even though they worked for Einstein, or Edison, or some random CEO of a tech startup or whoever.)  People feel well informed at the end of a green book, and are tricked into thinking they're now armed to the teeth with effective strategies for success. But they're not. It still takes as much time, effort, and experimentation to sort through this mess of ideas and separate the wheat from the chaff as it would take for somebody to just figure things out on their own in the first place without reading this long-winded book.  Seriously, any given Green book could be 10% the length. But nope, he's gotta prove to everybody how much he knows. We gotta learn Thomas Edison's entire f*cking life story before we can receive the singular pearl of wisdom that perseverance is effective (sometimes. other times, not.)

And he raised his head and looked upon the people, and there fell a stillness upon them. And with a great voice he said:      When love beckons to you, follow him,      Though his ways are hard and steep. Like sheaves of corn he gathers you unto himself      He threshes you to make your naked.      He sifts you to free you from your husks.      He grinds you to whiteness.      He kneads you until you are pliant;      And then he assigns you to his sacred fire, that you may become sacred bread for Godâ€™s sacred feast.       All these things shall love do unto you that you may know the secrets of your heart, and in that knowledge become a fragment of Lifeâ€™s heart.       But if in your heart you would seek only loveâ€™s peace and loveâ€™s pleasure,      Then it is better for you that you cover your nakedness and pass out of loveâ€™s threshing-floor,      Into the seasonless world where you shall laugh, but not all of your laughter, and weep, but not all of your tears.      Love gives naught but itself and takes naught but from itself.      Love possesses not nor would it be possessed;      For love is sufficient unto love.       When you love you should not say, â€œGod is in my heart,â€ but rather, â€œI am in the heart of God.â€      And think not you can direct the course of love, for love, if it finds you worthy, directs your course.       Love has no other desire but to fulfil itself.      But if you love and must needs have desires, let these be your desires:      To melt and be like a running brook that sings its melody to the night.      To know the pain of too much tenderness.      To be wounded by your own understanding of love;      And to bleed willingly and joyfully.      To wake at dawn with a winged heart and give thanks for another day of loving;      To rest at the noon hour and meditate loveâ€™s ecstasy;      To return home at eventide with gratitude;      And then to sleep with a prayer for the beloved in your heart and a song of praise upon your lips.

The sublime, the liminal, the subaltern; these are all descriptions of the spaces that we cannot occupy in any direct sense but which we all pass through at some point in our lives. Some of us live closer to these spaces than others but the majority of the time we live in the profane or non sacred spaces of our ordinary lives. The more we can recognize our proximity to these moments of passage the better we are able to handle them and also the greater the chances become for inspiration and growth. The idea of killing time is the unconscious feeling between these moments of transcendent experience. I think instead of humans attempting to murder time, perhaps instead we are seeing the process of a toxic mimicking. Those who are lost within any addiction or post trauma behavior that negatively impacts them are essentially attempting to escape the painful and dull profanity of a life which has not allowed them to experience or benefit from these moments. We are both afraid of these experiences and also deeply yearn for them. We use religion or other forms of containment in order to make them less scary and yet in this way we end up caging and taming the essential qualities of wildness, mystery, and we often end up further alienating ourselves from ever passing through these moments consciously. When we learn to accept the fact that there are spaces where transformation becomes possible we are more likely to enjoy life and we feel less insecure about change, whether internal or otherwise. It remains mysterious and uncomfortable however instead of fear or denial we develop our connection with everyone and the compassion necessary for self acceptance and self awareness. From this perspective we can recognize places where growth is possible and the sublime becomes more easy to recognize when it is occurring.

Please talk about Dr. Paul Eckman's work on facial expressions and body language. When we feel an emotion it sets off muscular contractions throughout the body that you can try to hide and control but always show up somewhere for a fraction of a second at least. That means when you watch a video and feeling an emotion you are in fact exercising that/those emotion(s).  It also means that an emotion is actually the impact of a stimulus being interpreted by the body through a series of specific muscular contractions.  Each time the body has an electrical signal sent through it, the current basically burns a path from the muscles being used to the brain, with that path becoming bigger wider and easier to follow without using excess energy on focusing where to go, but big paths always pull things to them, so if too much current is introduced it can overwhelm the muscles around it in order to take the big path... and that big path today, my friend, is as you mentioned... it is geared towards evil in all its many faucets.
